title: Tuesday, 31st July, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

It's nearly August!

Blank canvas good morning everyone
AAAA salut !
Manxish Morning each

Any you know what that means? It means it's nearly time for the AV team to be put into their Cocoon-type storage pods for a fortnight, to give everyone a break from each other.

Grouchmonkey Bonjour
Blank canvas August equals sad face for us then
Cloudy And we're nearly at the third decade of the 21st C.
nightingale20201 morning....
hornblower hello. any comment on Greggs or Greencore. looks like sandwiches doing better than sausage rolls
BE11:07am

The current plan, I think, is to go semi-dark from the week beginning August 20th, so you're not getting rid of us yet.

Soundbuy Morning all
Playing FTSE Morgen
11:07 am
BE11:08am

Though if there's not more interesting news soon I may take a unilateral decision.

nightingale20201 so three more weeks??
undefined
Soundbuy More time to spend with the children...........crikey............
BE11:08am

Today, we have Japan and we have results! Billions and billions of results!

Grouchmonkey @Hornblower thought Greggs was quite impressive given that, in 30 deg heat, no-one, but no-one, wants a hot pie
11:08 am
BE11:09am

Which we'll do by request.

hedgehog travis
Tom Dalgleish 17C here
Tom Dalgleish Surf rolling in
Soundbuy Early request for Smurfit tomorrow...........
BE11:11am

Let's start with a bit of Japan macro though. A surprise nothing overnight, apart from a big doc called "Strengthening the Framework for
Continuous Powerful Monetary Easing".

Tom Dalgleish Tech taking a sympathy dive over here
Soundbuy Greggs and Greencore..............sarnie city...........
Grouchmonkey @Tom where is "here"?
Tom Dalgleish Near Perth. Oz in general
BE11:12am

The upshot is that the BOJ introduced forward guidance for
policy rates; changed the size of the policy-rate balance; and changed the
composition of its ETF purchases.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

What does this add up to? Here's Nomura.

BE11:13am

The BOJ has said that it will reduce the size of the policy-rate balance in financial institutions' current account balances at the Bank, to which a negative interest rate is applied, from the current level of about ¥10trn on average, adding in its release about the review of the benchmark ratio used to calculate the macro add-on balance that it expected the policy-rate balance to be around ¥5trn. This move looks designed to deal with one of the side-effects of its policies to date, namely relatively large balances attracting negative interest rates at trust banks and other financial institutions subject to reserve requirements.

BE11:14am

From 6 August 2018 onwards, the BOJ will purchase ETFs that track the TOPIX, Nikkei 225, and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 at ratios of 87%, 11%, and 1% respectively (these three percentages do not total 100% because of rounding). This move looks designed to deal with another side-effect of its policies to date, namely excessive purchases of certain stocks. However, another way of looking at this is that it has given itself room for maneuver by retaining its exposure to the Nikkei 225. ETF purchases of ¥6trn should still boost the Nikkei 225 by 2,000 points, for example.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Meanwhile, the BOJ continued to say that it would purchase ETFs and REITs so that their amounts outstanding will increase at annual paces of about ¥6trn and about ¥90bn, respectively, but added that it might increase or decrease the amount of purchases depending on market conditions, with a view to encouraging appropriate risk premiums on asset prices. These decisions have given the BOJ strong discretion over ETF purchases as well as 10-year JGB yields, thereby making it harder to gauge the pace of purchases. Basically, we think that the BOJ is poised to taper ETF purchases, but it is unclear what amount of share price volatility it will be prepared to accept. We will be looking for BOJ statements and actual purchases to shed more light on these uncertainties.

BE11:15am

And HSBC for an overview.

Playing FTSE JustEat -5%, bottom of the bluechips; Travis -11% footing the 250
BE11:16am

[The BOj said that[ while keeping the 10-year yield target at around 0% under the yield curve control (YCC) policy, there may be more upward and downward movement in 10-year yields.The flexibility, in our view, is geared towards the sustainability of the current monetary policy and more volatility in the JGB market. While the gradual reduction in JGB purchases has already been set in place (Figure 1), the subtle change the BoJ has introduced is a wider band for the YCC, doubling the implicit band of +- 10bp to +-20bp. We expect the 10-year JGB yield to gradually rise to 0.15% by year-end.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The tweak in policy may partly address the issue of declining profitability of financial institutions with greater variability in JGB yields, enhancing market making activity and allowing slightly higher yields in the 2-10yr segment. However, the introduction of forward guidance and a strong commitment towards very low rates for an extended period of time is likely to lead to a flattening of the yield curve in the super-long segment i.e. +20yr. Such a flattening of the curve should actually enhance the relative appeal of foreign bonds vs JGBs and encourage more outward bond investments from Japan. Major bond markets such as Australia and France are likely to remain key targets for major Japanese investors.

undefined
BE11:17am

And so, to corporate.

Maverick Morning gents, by any chance Bryce is Greencore on your radar again? Seemed very much your cup of tea a couple of months back...
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Starting at the bottom. Just Sell

Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 798.50, down 47.9 (-5.66%), High: 841.80, Low: 791.40, Volume: 2.77m

There's two, or arguably, three parts to this.

Pharma @Playing FTSE "JustEat bottom of the bluechips"Two words that should never have ended up in the same sentence.

The first is the siren song of all consumer tech companies: They're growing revenue but they're having to reinvest it at a far faster pace than anyone thought likely a few years ago.

BE11:20am

From Facebook down to .......... I dunno, that silly Burmese thing on Aim.

They all need to hire more actual people to monitor stuff, spend more to upgrade the systems far more often than anyone guessed, and require ever increasing marketing budgets.

Is there a company that hasn't warned along these lines? Asos has. Rightmove has. MoneySupermarket has. Just Eat has, again and again.

BE11:23am

so -- revenue guidance up to where consensus was, but earnings don't follow because there's another £5 to £10m in the investment budget

11:23 am

Second ......... UK orders are terrible

BE11:23am

20% growth for H1, meaning Q2 was just 16%.

BE11:23am

Why?

rw42 Sure software dev is like a lot of industries where maintenance is stripped back up till something breaks, then they fess up they'll have to spend more money doing what they should have been doing from the start..

BE11:24am

Given they folded in the Hungryhouse customer base in late May, that slowdown is a real concern.

jaws gm

Blame goes, yep, on weather

jaws anything in VOD or Games workshop please ?

There's some good stuff in the archive about how sensitive takeaway orders are to weather.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Third, Australia.

BE11:26am

Where revenue's down 8%.

Dorian Gray surely you'd expect world cup to help orders? no?
BE11:27am

Oz is a smallish market so it's not that significant in a group sense, but still .....

11:27 am
BE11:27am

........... the assumption here is that UberEats has gone into Australia and taken the market

BE11:28am

And if they can do it there ..... etc.

BE11:28am

Here comes JP Morgan.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Overall, JUST EAT’s results today are broadly in line with expectations while slowing growth in the UK and Australia are clearly negatives (though Canada and International better than expected). Given that the company maintained EBITDA guidance (see below) for the year, we do not expect upgrades on the back of these results.

BE11:29am

We highlighted before that the company had "kitchen-sinked" its FY18 guidance to £660m-700m group revenues previously (JPMe £733m and buy-side consensus into H118 numbers was at c£750m) and thus expect limited/no consensus upgrades today. Management raised investment guidance to £55m-60m (from £50m previously) and reiterated FY18 underlying EBITDA expectations of £165m-185m (JPMe £184m).

BE11:29am

In our analysis of the UK market, we argued that as a result of the delayed move into delivery, JUST EAT’s disproportionate exposure to the lower price restaurant segment brings strategic disadvantages versus Deliveroo/UberEats. Overall, we keep our view that Delivery Hero (OW, one of our top picks) as the far better option to play the theme.

Tom Dalgleish So if commerce is bifurcating into online and traditional where trad has need to enter a coding arms race, won’t it be the the ultimate survivor
11:30 am
BE11:30am

They're sellers. Macquarie are buyers.

Tom Dalgleish *has no need
BE11:30am

 The in-line EBITDA combined with revenue outperformance confirm our view that 2018 is a year of investment. We believe Just Eat’s overall growth outlook remains strong but any potential earnings outperformance will likely be reinvested. In our view, Just Eat needs to invest in marketing and delivery to reach critical mass since it is late to the market and faces more competition from delivery platforms than direct peers.
 We reiterate our positive view on Canada. Anglo Saxon markets offer
exceptional potential and we see no reason why the Canadian market cannot achieve similarly high penetration and growth potential.

BE11:31am

Action and recommendation
 We believe Just Eat is long-term undervalued. It trades at 6.6x EV/2019
Sales compared to 8.4x for Takeaway.com, which offers only marginally higher growth of 31% vs 25% at Just Eat (Q1 2018). Moreover, Just Eat is highly profitable (2017: 24% EBITDA margin) vs Takewaway.com (-17%).

11:31 am
BE11:31am

"We believe Just Eat is long-term undervalued. It trades at 6.6x EV/2019
Sales" .... yeah, it's up to you whether you want to keep reading after that bit.

undefined
BE11:32am

@Jaws mentions Vodafone

Tom Dalgleish EV....assuming the enterprise has any value
11:32 am
BE11:33am

Shares popped yesterday afternoon on a Dealreporter article saying Elliott had a maiden stake of unknown size

BE11:33am

We're led to believe that report was accurate, for what it's worth.

BE11:34am

Though activist stories always make me a bit wary, particularly when they're below the disclosure limit.

Tax Realist Is the Elementis deal getting pulled?
11:35 am
BE11:35am

The shares pop, inevitably, meaning it all feels very self serving to publicise an activist's de minimis punt when you have no clarity on what that specific punt is and whether they'll sell out.

Soundbuy Elliot's busy......................
Grouchmonkey Yes, also interested in the Elements story. I can't recall too many RNSs which specifically refer to shareholders not liking the deal the company proposed. Sounds likely to be pulled?
BE11:36am

We can go though the arguments of Vodafone value creation though.

Grouchmonkey *Elementis* Thanks spellcheck
BE11:36am

Just in case an activist wants to get involved with a stake that would become public knowledge because it was significant enough to be in management/s thinking.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Which, to be extremely boring and repetitive on the point, is not what we have here.

BE11:37am

Here's Berenberg.

BE11:38am

What might be Elliott’s angle? The market does not buy into Vodafone management’s assessment that there is no balance sheet issue at the company. This is reflected in an equity free cash flow yield that is approaching 9% for 2019, on our estimates. While we agree with management that consistent delivery on EBITDA growth should dispel the balance sheet fears over time, an activist like Elliott might see a quicker route to correcting the disconnect – perhaps by encouraging a reluctant Vodafone to consider tower sales more proactively. This is a less obvious, but potentially sizeable, opportunity to extract value than any of the obvious and, in our view, less straightforward asset sales.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

o Netherlands JV with Liberty: Both Vodafone and Liberty Global have a right to initiate an IPO of their stake but not before January 2020. A sale to a third-party can only be initiated in January 2021.
o India: We cannot imagine there will be any buyers for the JV given its size and current market uncertainty. Vodafone is already progressing well in monetising the tower assets in India to reduce the debt load.
o Australia/New Zealand: Vodafone management is already on top of this.
o AMAP: Key assets here are in South Africa, Egypt and Turkey. Vodacom in South Africa is one of Vodafone’s best assets. In Egypt, Vodafone benefits from shared service centres, and Turkey is difficult to sell at the moment.
● Towers opportunity – pros outweigh the cons: It

BE11:39am

... must be said upfront that most operators sell towers for financial reasons. Vodafone management clearly does not think it has a pressing need today so convincing it otherwise is going to need some agitating.

BE11:39am

There's a lot more about towers. I'll kip to the working.

Swedes Not at or above the disclosure limit as too much risk?
jaws BE thank you.
11:40 am
BE11:40am

The tower maths looks like a no-brainer but it requires convinction that there is a problem that needs solving: Lately KKR has been very active in acquiring tower assets. The average value realised in European tower sales is c€240,000 per tower, ranging from €90,000 in Spain to €417,000 in the Netherlands. The most recent sales in France and Portugal attracted values of €350,000 and €225,000 respectively. The location of the towers, whether in a rural or urban area, the backhaul (fibre or otherwise) as well as land ownership are some factors. For Vodafone, a sale of 50,000 towers (half its portfolio) at a value per tower of €250,000 would yield as much as €12.5bn. This would cut Vodafone’s absolute debt load of €32bn by 40%.

wayneJ Never understood the logic of selling towers - unless the cost of leasing them back is less than your cost of capital - and u do not get hit by strategic issues
BE11:41am

... which looks a fair argument, given the stock's at a five-year low or whatever.

wayneJ Or in other words does a highly levered KKR entity have a lower cost of debt than Vodafone?
wayneJ Or can Vodafone actually securitise the towers itself
BE11:42am

Alongside that we have the inevitable Vod-Liberty debate.

wayneJ (Towers are good assets for an operator to use to barter access to other towers etc)
Bluesky21 @ Wayne - on towers, is the more relevant comparison not the cost of NewCo debt with Vodafone’s equity?
11:42 am
BE11:42am

First, could an activist try to block the Vodafone-Liberty deal?

wayneJ (And I say that having once tried to buy 10k towers with a couple of friends).
Tom Dalgleish so KKR will lease them to all and sundry
BE11:43am

And push for a share buyback instead? I think Merrill was putting that idea around yesterday.

wayneJ @Bluesky - rather newco debt vs vod debt - and whether deleveraging will lower the risk and so improve the cost of debt + equity
Bluesky21 @ Wayne - FTSE companies get grief if their leverage goes above 2x; private equity seems happy to go above 5x any day ...
BE11:44am

The answer is "probably not", as Liberty is a Class 2 transaction under UKLA rules so doesn't need a shareholder vote.

Bluesky21 @ Wayne - yes, but as a Vodafone shareholder, you are being paid for your equity with funds financed by NewCo debt
wayneJ @Tom - that is how u make money as a tower infrastructure company - by going multitenanted. The issue for an operator is that it can screw your access to a tower. And anyway eg in countries like the UK operators can share without the help of a third party
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Plus, management provided all the maths for EPS accretion on a buyback when announcing the Liberty deal instead. And if it breaks you have the leakage of a €250m break fee to offset any theoretical gain.

Bluesky21 @ WayneJ - for the same EBITDA, private equity can sustain a much higher enterprise value by virtue of a higher mutliple of debt - this being the most relevant outcome, interest rate of the debt just being one of the inputs
wayneJ @Bluesky indirectly you are right (ie cut vod debt and improve the equity rating etc.) - but there are other ways to do it - eg put the towers into a non-recourse securitisation vehicle.
BE11:46am

As for the eternally uncovered divi, here's JP Morgan.

Bluesky21 Good point, but are there many examples of such non-recourse securitisation vehicles?
wayneJ @Bluesky - that is the anomaly of capital markets that makes no sense to me - especially given that the private equity backed cos still use public markets for the debt or for an exit of the equity.
nichoman Elliot seems to have fingers in a lot of pies now. becoming more like a regular fund manager with more of an activist tilt?
Bluesky21 I suspect the equity of such non-recourse securitation vehicles will not be adequately valued by public markets, so there will be calls to divest, and we end up the same place
wayneJ @Bluesky - a great example where the owner blinked was the Broadgate complex owned by British Land - they blinked and sold half of it to Blackstone at the wrong price at the bottom of the mkt
BE11:48am

With Vodafone’s

Bluesky21 Interesting. Mark-to-market is the enemy of good investing
11:48 am
BE11:48am

dividend of E4.2bn

BE11:48am

barely covered by recurring EFCF post normalized spectrum payments, investors have long debated the sustainability of this yield. This has raised question marks around whether Vodafone should: 1. change it’s shareholder returns policy in favour of buybacks, thereby lowering it’s share count and hence the overall size of annual dividend payments, 2. use asset sales to drive buybacks, with this again focused on creating a more sustainable looking dividend distribution policy. Whilst an understandable debate, we personally do not think Vodafone’s dividend policy should determine it’s strategic priorities.

wayneJ The other bit of fun is sorting out the transfer of ownership and checking all the paperwork is correct. The transaction I was involved in - lets say some of the paperwork even the operators had no idea where it was....
BE11:49am

(You may ask why I had to quote in three boxes. It's because the ML text entry systems is a bag of spanners.)

Guidance raised.

Bluesky21 Let’s not forget Elliot has been involved in Telecom Italia; so no stranger to incumbent national telcos
BE11:52am

And since we mention Pfizer, we may as well go to a major supplier of customers of Lipitor

Greggs PLC (GRG:LSE): Last: 1,034, up 72.5 (+7.54%), High: 1,063, Low: 978.00, Volume: 566.42k
Bluesky21 @ WayneJ - surely Vodafone can get cheaper legal
11:53 am
BE11:53am

H1 ebit down 7%, but that's fine. Like-for-likes look reassuring.

wayneJ Given I wrote the business plan for the above mentioned project u could argue about poacher turned gamekeeper but selling towers, if you are a well financed company, is strategic suicide because nice people like me will charge u for power, for backhaul, for each slot etc and have nice gentle price escalators built in.....
jaws ESUR 202 and PRU better ?
wayneJ @Bluesky - lets just say the price of a tower is inversely proportional to the circulation of brown envelopes in an economy....
BE11:54am

Similar to the Just Eat story, it's weather related plus investment related and expansion related. The difference is that Greggs is on about 15 times earnings rather than 6 times EV/sales.

Bluesky21 @ WayneJ - thanks for sharing all these. I had worked in places that own telcos, but it’s fascinating to hear someone else’s experience all the same
BE11:54am

Here's Canaccord.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Greggs' interims were a tad below our expectations with PBT (Adj.) of £25.9m versus CGe forecast of £27m. Nevertheless, we view this as a resilient performance despite the extremes of weather (both hot and cold). Greggs continues to believe that full year underlying profits will be similar to last year and we make only minor changes to our forecasts. 2018 is an important year for Greggs as it marks the investment peak in the production and supply chain transformation to a national platform. This will allow it to capture the economies of scale that it could never achieve in a regional set-up.

wayneJ And 'regularising' a tower - when everyone on the other side knows that as a proper company you have to do that - can get expensive - you will find things crawl out the woodwork....
Bluesky21 If Greggs like-for-like is +1.5%, is that enough to cover their cost inflation, especially with National Living Wage pushing wages up +3% to +4% a year?
BE11:56am

Detail
Interim revenue rose by +5.2% (L4L +1.5%, new stores +3.7%) but the 70bps fall in EBIT margin to 5.4% drove the reduction in underlying EBIT to £25.9m (vs £27.6m in H1 2017). Salads/cold drinks are less profitable than savories/coffee.
During the period Greggs opened 59 new shops (including 19 franchised) and closed 25 shops giving a total of 1888 shops at end June. Greggs now expects to open net 100 stores in FY18 (60 franchise, 40 owned). The reduction in guidance from 110-130 shops reflects a slightly more cautious approach from franchise-partner Euro-Garages. FY18 is a record year for supply-chain investment which is part of a bigger three-year plan. Recent activity has focused on new national dough-nut production, internal relocation of pizza production and adapting logistics to cope with the increasingly national production. In addition, Greggs has announced plans to build a new distribution centre at Amesbury in Wiltshire next year to service the South-West. It also plans to replace HR and payroll systems and introduce a new estate management system. Once complete it will have the capacity to grow to c.2,500 shops, a 32% increase in shop capacity. Capex is running at c.£90m pa but should revert to maintenance levels from 2021; in addition, we expect Greggs to sell the Twickenham site (c.£20m value) in the next 18 months. It continues to run a net cash balance, so we would expect a resumption of special dividends in the next couple of years.

Bluesky21 Or can they squeeze more out of their supply chain again? Put less sausage in sausage rolls?
BE11:56am

And Peel Hunt.

wayneJ If I told you that some operators do not actually quite know where all their towers are! Or if they own them all. Once we started digging we found all kinds of amazing stuff - eg paying leases to people who were not the freeholders of the land!
11:56 am
BE11:56am

LFL sales growth returned in May and June and that ensured
Greggs produced a satisfactory set of interims this morning. It is
clear that customer focus has moved towards the bottom end of
the menu, with deals doing well, but given the unseasonal nature
of May and June, a 2% LFL print for those months is perfectly
solid and allays some of our fears. Greggs is a solid, well managed
business but forecast momentum is flat at best, and with the
shares on a mid-teen PE, they are of limited interest to us. We
would use the strength in the shares following the figures as an
opportunity to switch into another retailer where the same PE
brings more momentum.

Bluesky21 And what does having a higher and higher mix of franchises do to Gregg’s economics?
BE11:57am

Just reading below the line here ..............

BE11:57am

The attempts to bring customers into the stores in the afternoon and into
the evenings has evolved: management is offering a pizza slice and a drink for £2 after 4pm: it is trying to become “famous” for something here, just like customers love the £2 breakfast and drink. Pizza may or may not be the answer, but maximising the appeal when the stores are open is important.

wayneJ Is Greggs the UK equivalent of Doctors' Associates (parent of Subway)?
11:58 am
BE11:59am

Amazing. The reinvention of the $1 pizza slice. Just like The Bronx, except you get a milky coffee.

Bluesky21 Greggs management like talking about how many stores Subways plan to build in the UK, so yes
undefined

Soundbuy Greencore?

BE12:00pm

Bluesky21 Sky - one of the very few stocks Crispin Odey gets right

Blank canvas thanks for everything today

Greencore Group PLC (GNC:LSE): Last: 187.20, up 0.2 (+0.11%), High: 197.70, Low: 183.90, Volume: 5.93m

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Quick line from Davy.

BE12:02pm

Greencore’s Q3 update suggests that revenue growth is running
ahead of our expectations. This is largely driven by Convenience
Foods North America, where revenue growth has benefited from
business wins and category growth. Lacklustre category growth in
the Food-to-Go (FtG) segment was the only blemish in the
statement; however, management commentary confirms a volume
recovery through July. Our model already assumes a moderation
in FtG revenue growth for FY2019 (to 3%). The year continues to
be characterised by change – across customer, asset and
management levels. We do not foresee any material change to
consensus EPS forecasts post the update.

Bluesky21 The Board in the shape of senior independent director Martin Gilbert
wayneJ @Bluesky - but he / Disney can sit tight - and have creeping control
Maverick @Soundbuy Greencore has previously been reported as attracting private equity interest. I'm interested in if this interest is rekindling...
sprout Bluesky - I'm invested in one of Odey's funds and it's up 12% year to date, after costs. Things he gets wrong get a lot more notice than what he gets right.
BE12:03pm

19% LFL at Peacock's obviously the highlight there.

wayneJ And not sure all the Murdoch standstill agreements still hold for Disney
Bluesky21 When Fox tried to buy out Sky before Disney/Comcast, there was a long explanation about why having Sky being part of Fox helps - not least with Germany and Europe@ Sprout - I am sorry to hear that. Would losing 46% in 2017 and 25% in 2016 (from memory) count as how he gets more right than wrong?

And as to the PE story .... we heard speculation a while ago that Greencore had had an approach and then nothing whatsoever happened so, pending further fresh speculation, we have to assume nothing's happening.

Gist with Centrica is that too many boilers broke down during the Beast from the East .....
